{"step_by_step_thinking": "The baby's symptoms of poor feeding, high-pitched cry, diaphoresis, hyperreflexia, tremors, and an excessive startle response, along with the mother's frequent use of codeine syrup, suggest neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS). NAS is a postnatal drug withdrawal syndrome that primarily occurs in opioid-exposed infants. The management of NAS is based on the severity of the withdrawal symptoms. Nonpharmacologic care is the mainstay of treatment and includes minimizing environmental stimuli and promoting good nutrition and adequate rest. However, infants with moderate to severe NAS, as in this case, often require pharmacologic therapy. Morphine is the most commonly used first-line agent for the treatment of opioid withdrawal in neonates.", "answer_choice": "A"}
